adjective.description: Not firmly or tightly fixed in place; detached or able to be detached.
(of a garment) not fitting tightly or closely.
examples: she slipped into a loose T-shirt and shorts

adjective.description: Not close or compact in structure.
Engaging in casual sexual encounters or relationships.
examples: she ran the risk of being called a loose woman
synonyms: no better than one should be

phrases: Hopefully this will restore my good humour: I need to hang loose and laugh for an hour or so.
Besides, I figured I could do more good if I stayed loose.
Some enjoy jabbering to everyone in sight, listening to music, and staying loose.
The key I believe is to stay loose and just write whatever pops into your head.
origin: Middle English loos free from bonds, from Old Norse lauss, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German los.
